name: Segmentation
definition: Divide an object into independent parts, make it easy to disassemble, and increase the degree of fragmentation or segmentation.
guidelines: Divide an object into independent parts.
Make an object easy to disassemble.
Increase the degree of fragmentation or segmentation.
examples: Replace a mainframe computer by personal computers.
Replace a large truck by a truck and trailer.
Use a work breakdown structure for a large project.
Use modular furniture.
Use quick disconnect joints in plumbing.
Replace solid shades with Venetian blinds.
Use powdered welding metal instead of foil or rod to get better penetration of the joint.

name: Taking out
definition: Separate an interfering part or property from an object, or single out only the necessary part or property.
guidelines: Separate an interfering part or property from an object.
Single out the only necessary part or property of an object.
examples: Locate a noisy compressor outside the building where compressed air is used.
Use fiber optics or a light pipe to separate the hot light source from the location where light is needed.
Use the sound of a barking dog, without the dog, as a burglar alarm.

name: Local quality
definition: Change structure or environment from uniform to non-uniform, and make each part operate in conditions best suited to it, often with different useful functions.
guidelines: Change an object's structure from uniform to non-uniform.
Change an external environment or external influence from uniform to non-uniform.
Make each part of an object function in conditions most suitable for its operation.
Make each part of an object fulfill a different and useful function.
examples: Use a temperature, density, or pressure gradient instead of constant temperature, density, or pressure.
Use a lunch box with special compartments for hot and cold solid foods and for liquids.
Use a pencil with an eraser.
Use a hammer with a nail puller.
Use a multi-function tool that scales fish, acts as pliers, a wire stripper, a flat-blade screwdriver, a Phillips screwdriver, a manicure set, etc.

name: Asymmetry
definition: Change the shape of an object from symmetrical to asymmetrical or increase its degree of asymmetry.
guidelines: Change the shape of an object from symmetrical to asymmetrical.
If an object is asymmetrical, increase its degree of asymmetry.
examples: Use asymmetrical mixing vessels or asymmetrical vanes in symmetrical vessels to improve mixing (cement trucks, cake mixers, blenders).
Put a flat spot on a cylindrical shaft to attach a knob securely.
Change from circular O-rings to oval cross-section to specialized shapes to improve sealing.
Use astigmatic optics to merge colors.

name: Merging
definition: Bring identical or similar objects closer together or merge them, and make operations contiguous or parallel.
guidelines: Bring closer together or merge identical or similar objects.
Assemble identical or similar parts to perform parallel operations.
Make operations contiguous or parallel, bringing them together in time.
examples: Use personal computers in a network.
Use thousands of microprocessors in a parallel processor computer.
Use vanes in a ventilation system.
Mount electronic chips on both sides of a circuit board or subassembly.
Link slats together in Venetian or vertical blinds.
Use medical diagnostic instruments that analyze multiple blood parameters simultaneously.
Use a mulching lawnmower.

name: Universality
definition: Make a part or object perform multiple functions, eliminating the need for other parts.
guidelines: Make a part or object perform multiple functions.
Eliminate the need for other parts by combining functions.
examples: Use a toothbrush handle that contains toothpaste.
Use a child’s car safety seat that converts to a stroller.
Use a mulching lawnmower (demonstrates both Merging and Universality).
Have a team leader also act as recorder and timekeeper.
Use a CCD with micro-lenses formed on the surface.

name: Nested doll
definition: Place one object inside another or make one part pass through a cavity in another.
guidelines: Place one object inside another.
Place each object, in turn, inside another.
Make one part pass through a cavity in the other.
examples: Use measuring cups or spoons that nest inside one another.
Use Russian dolls.
Use a portable audio system where the microphone fits inside the transmitter, which fits inside the amplifier case.
Use an extending radio antenna.
Use an extending pointer.
Use a zoom lens.
Use a seat belt retraction mechanism.
Use retractable aircraft landing gear that stows inside the fuselage.

name: Anti-weight
definition: Compensate for the weight of an object by merging it with lift-providing objects or by interacting with the environment.
guidelines: To compensate for the weight of an object, merge it with other objects that provide lift.
To compensate for the weight of an object, make it interact with the environment using aerodynamic, hydrodynamic, buoyancy, or other forces.
examples: Inject a foaming agent into a bundle of logs to make it float better.
Use a helium balloon to support advertising signs.
Use an aircraft wing shape that reduces air density above the wing and increases density below to create lift.
Use vortex strips to improve lift of aircraft wings.
Use hydrofoils to lift a ship out of the water to reduce drag.

name: Preliminary anti-action
definition: Replace an action with both harmful and useful effects by pre-applied anti-actions, or create stresses beforehand to oppose later undesirable stresses.
guidelines: If an action has both harmful and useful effects, replace it with anti-actions to control harmful effects.
Create beforehand stresses in an object that will oppose known undesirable working stresses later on.
examples: Buffer a solution to prevent harm from extremes of pH.
Pre-stress rebar before pouring concrete.
Use a lead apron on body parts not being exposed to X-rays.
Use masking tape to protect the part of an object not being painted.

name: Preliminary action
definition: Perform required changes to an object in advance, fully or partially, and pre-arrange objects for quick action.
guidelines: Perform, before it is needed, the required change of an object either fully or partially.
Pre-arrange objects such that they can come into action from the most convenient place without losing time for delivery.
examples: Use pre-pasted wallpaper.
Sterilize all instruments needed for a surgical procedure on a sealed tray.
Use Kanban arrangements in a Just-In-Time factory.
Use a flexible manufacturing cell.

name: Beforehand cushioning
definition: Prepare emergency means beforehand to compensate for the relatively low reliability of an object.
guidelines: Prepare emergency means beforehand to compensate for low reliability.
examples: Use a magnetic strip on photographic film that directs the developer to compensate for poor exposure.
Use a back-up parachute.
Use an alternate air system for aircraft instruments.

name: Equipotentiality
definition: Reduce or eliminate position changes in a potential field by changing operating conditions or system design.
guidelines: In a potential field, limit position changes.
Change operating conditions to eliminate the need to raise or lower objects in a gravity field.
examples: Use a spring-loaded parts delivery system in a factory.
Use locks in a channel between two bodies of water, as in the Panama Canal.
Use skillets in an automobile plant that bring all tools to the right position.

name: The other way round
definition: Invert actions, swap fixed and movable parts, or turn the object/process upside down.
guidelines: Invert the action used to solve the problem.
Make movable parts or the external environment fixed, and fixed parts movable.
Turn the object or process upside down.
examples: To loosen stuck parts, cool the inner part instead of heating the outer part.
Bring the mountain to Mohammed instead of Mohammed to the mountain.
Rotate the part instead of the tool.
Use a moving sidewalk with standing people.
Use a treadmill for walking or running in place.
Turn an assembly upside down to insert fasteners.
Empty grain from containers by inverting them.

name: Spheroidality – Curvature
definition: Use curvilinear parts, surfaces, and motions instead of rectilinear ones, and employ rotary motion and centrifugal forces.
guidelines: Instead of rectilinear parts, surfaces, or forms, use curvilinear ones.
Move from flat surfaces to spherical ones and from cube-shaped parts to ball-shaped structures.
Use rollers, balls, spirals, domes.
Go from linear to rotary motion and use centrifugal forces.
examples: Use arches and domes for strength in architecture.
Use a spiral gear to produce continuous resistance for weight lifting.
Use ball point and roller point pens for smooth ink distribution.
Produce linear motion of a cursor using a mouse or trackball.
Replace wringing clothes to remove water with spinning clothes in a washing machine.
Use spherical casters instead of cylindrical wheels to move furniture.

name: Dynamics
definition: Allow characteristics of an object or process to change, divide it into movable parts, or make rigid systems flexible or adaptive.
guidelines: Allow or design characteristics of an object, environment, or process to change to be optimal.
Divide an object into parts capable of movement relative to each other.
If an object or process is rigid or inflexible, make it movable or adaptive.
examples: Use an adjustable steering wheel, seat, back support, or mirror position.
Use a butterfly computer keyboard.
Use a flexible boroscope for examining engines.
Use a flexible sigmoidoscope for medical examination.

name: Partial or excessive actions
definition: Use slightly less or slightly more of a solution method when 100% is hard to achieve.
guidelines: If 100% of an effect is hard to achieve, use slightly less or slightly more of the same method to make the problem easier to solve.
examples: Overspray when painting, then remove excess.
Fill, then top off when filling a gas tank.

name: Another dimension
definition: Move an object in 2D or 3D space, stack objects vertically, tilt or reorient them, or use other sides of a given area.
guidelines: Move an object in two- or three-dimensional space.
Use a multi-story arrangement of objects instead of a single-story arrangement.
Tilt or re-orient the object.
Use another side of a given area.
examples: Use an infrared computer mouse that moves in space for presentations.
Use a five-axis cutting tool.
Use a cassette with six CDs to increase music time and variety.
Mount electronic chips on both sides of a printed circuit board.
Use tunnels below a theme park so employees disappear from customers and reappear elsewhere.
Use a dump truck by tilting the bed.
Stack microelectronic hybrid circuits to improve density.

name: Mechanical vibration
definition: Cause an object to oscillate or vibrate, adjust frequency, use resonance, or replace mechanical vibration with piezoelectric or combined fields.
guidelines: Cause an object to oscillate or vibrate.
Increase vibration frequency up to ultrasonic.
Use an object's resonant frequency.
Use piezoelectric vibrators instead of mechanical ones.
Use combined ultrasonic and electromagnetic field oscillations.
examples: Use an electric carving knife with vibrating blades.
Distribute powder with vibration.
Destroy gall stones or kidney stones using ultrasonic resonance.
Use quartz crystal oscillations to drive high-accuracy clocks.
Mix alloys in an induction furnace with combined oscillations.

name: Periodic action
definition: Replace continuous action with periodic or pulsating actions, adjust periodicity, and use pauses for other actions.
guidelines: Instead of continuous action, use periodic or pulsating actions.
If action is already periodic, change its magnitude or frequency.
Use pauses between impulses to perform a different action.
examples: Hit something repeatedly with a hammer instead of applying continuous pressure.
Replace a continuous siren with a pulsed sound.
Use Frequency Modulation to convey information instead of Morse code.
Replace a continuous siren with sound that changes amplitude and frequency.
In CPR, breathe after every five chest compressions.

name: Continuity of useful action
definition: Make all parts work continuously at full load and eliminate idle or intermittent actions.
guidelines: Carry on work continuously.
Make all parts of an object work at full load all the time.
Eliminate all idle or intermittent actions or work.
examples: Use a flywheel or hydraulic system to store energy when a vehicle stops so the motor can keep running at optimum power.
Run bottleneck operations in a factory continuously to reach the optimum pace.
Print during the return stroke of a printer carriage in dot matrix, daisy wheel, or inkjet printers.

name: Skipping
definition: Perform processes or certain stages at high speed, especially destructive, harmful, or hazardous operations.
guidelines: Conduct a process or certain stages at high speed to avoid negative effects.
examples: Use a high-speed dentist’s drill to avoid heating tissue.
Cut plastic faster than heat can propagate to avoid deforming the shape.

name: Blessing in disguise (Turn Lemons into Lemonade)
definition: Use harmful factors or effects to achieve positive results, combine harmful actions, or amplify them to neutralize harm.
guidelines: Use harmful factors, especially harmful effects of the environment or surroundings, to achieve a positive effect.
Eliminate the primary harmful action by adding it to another harmful action.
Amplify a harmful factor so much that it is no longer harmful.
examples: Use waste heat to generate electric power.
Recycle waste material from one process as raw materials for another.
Add a buffering material to a corrosive solution.
Use a helium-oxygen mix for diving to eliminate nitrogen narcosis and oxygen poisoning.
Use a backfire to eliminate fuel from a forest fire.

name: Feedback
definition: Introduce or adjust feedback to improve a process or action.
guidelines: Introduce feedback (referring back, cross-checking) to improve a process or action.
If feedback is already used, change its magnitude or influence.
examples: Use automatic volume control in audio circuits.
Use a signal from a gyrocompass to control simple aircraft autopilots.
Use Statistical Process Control measurements to decide when to modify a process.
Use budgets as a feedback mechanism for management.
Change sensitivity of an autopilot when within five miles of an airport.
Change thermostat sensitivity when cooling vs. heating.
Change a management measure from budget variance to customer satisfaction.

name: Intermediary
definition: Use an intermediary carrier object or process, or merge objects temporarily.
guidelines: Use an intermediary carrier article or intermediary process.
Merge one object temporarily with another that can be easily removed.
examples: Use a carpenter’s nailset between the hammer and the nail.
Use a pot holder to carry hot dishes to the table.

name: Self-service
definition: Make an object serve itself by performing auxiliary functions or using its own waste resources.
guidelines: Make an object serve itself by performing auxiliary helpful functions.
Use waste resources, energy, or substances.
examples: Use a soda fountain pump that runs on the pressure of carbon dioxide used to fizz drinks.
Use halogen lamps that regenerate the filament during use.
Weld steel to aluminum using an interface of alternating strips, then weld each side with normal techniques.
Use heat from a process to generate electricity (co-generation).
Use animal waste as fertilizer.
Use food and lawn waste to create compost.

name: Copying
definition: Replace expensive, fragile, or unavailable objects with simpler, inexpensive copies or optical copies.
guidelines: Instead of an unavailable, expensive, or fragile object, use simpler and inexpensive copies.
Replace an object or process with optical copies.
If visible optical copies are already used, move to infrared or ultraviolet copies.
examples: Use virtual reality via computer instead of an expensive vacation.
Listen to an audio tape instead of attending a seminar.
Do surveying from space photographs instead of on the ground.
Measure an object by measuring its photograph.
Make sonograms to evaluate the health of a fetus instead of direct invasive testing.
Make images in infrared to detect heat sources such as crop diseases or intruders.

name: Cheap short-living objects
definition: Replace an expensive object with many inexpensive, short-lived objects.
guidelines: Replace an inexpensive object with a multiple of inexpensive objects that together provide the needed qualities.
examples: Use disposable paper objects to avoid cleaning and storage costs.
Use plastic cups in motels.
Use disposable diapers.
Use disposable medical supplies.

name: Mechanics substitution
definition: Replace mechanical means with sensory or field-based means, and use structured or moving fields with responsive particles.
guidelines: Replace a mechanical means with a sensory (optical, acoustic, taste, or smell) means.
Use electric, magnetic, and electromagnetic fields to interact with the object.
Change from static to movable fields, from unstructured fields to structured fields.
Use fields in conjunction with field-activated particles.
examples: Replace a physical fence for animals with an acoustic fence.
Use a bad-smelling compound in natural gas to alert users to leakage.
To mix two powders, charge one positive and the other negative.
Use shaped antenna patterns in modern communications.
Heat a substance containing ferromagnetic material using a varying magnetic field until it passes the Curie point.

name: Pneumatics and hydraulics
definition: Use gas and liquid parts of an object instead of solid parts.
guidelines: Use gas and liquid parts of an object instead of solid parts (inflatable, hydrostatic, hydro-reactive, etc.).
examples: Use comfortable shoe sole inserts filled with gel.
Store energy from decelerating a vehicle in a hydraulic system and reuse it for acceleration.

name: Flexible shells and thin films
definition: Use flexible shells and thin films instead of three-dimensional structures or to isolate an object from the external environment.
guidelines: Use flexible shells and thin films instead of three-dimensional structures.
Isolate the object from the external environment using flexible shells and thin films.
examples: Use inflatable thin-film structures as winter covers on tennis courts.
Float a film of bipolar material on a reservoir to limit evaporation.

name: Porous materials
definition: Make an object porous or use its pores to introduce useful substances or functions.
guidelines: Make an object porous or add porous elements.
If an object is already porous, use the pores to introduce a useful substance or function.
examples: Drill holes in a structure to reduce weight.
Use a porous metal mesh to wick excess solder away from a joint.
Store hydrogen in the pores of a palladium sponge for fuel storage.

name: Color changes
definition: Change an object's color or its environment, or change transparency to achieve the desired effect.
guidelines: Change the color of an object or its external environment.
Change the transparency of an object or its external environment.
examples: Use safe lights in a photographic darkroom.
Use photolithography to change transparent material to a solid mask for semiconductor processing.
Change mask material from transparent to opaque for silk screen processing.

name: Homogeneity
definition: Use interacting objects made of the same or similar materials to reduce unwanted effects.
guidelines: Make objects interacting with a given object from the same material or with identical properties.
examples: Make a container out of the same material as the contents to reduce chemical reactions.
Make a diamond cutting tool out of diamonds.

name: Discarding and recovering
definition: Discard parts that have fulfilled their function or restore consumable parts during operation.
guidelines: Make portions of an object that have fulfilled their functions go away by dissolving, evaporating, etc.
Modify consumable parts directly during operation or restore them.
examples: Use a dissolving capsule for medicine.
Sprinkle water on cornstarch-based packaging to drastically reduce its volume.
Use ice or dry ice as a temporary template for rammed earth structures.
Use self-sharpening lawn mower blades.
Use automobile engines that tune themselves while running.

name: Parameter changes
definition: Change an object's physical state, concentration, flexibility, or temperature.
guidelines: Change an object's physical state (gas, liquid, solid).
Change the concentration or consistency.
Change the degree of flexibility.
Change the temperature.
examples: Freeze liquid centers of candies before dipping in melted chocolate.
Transport oxygen, nitrogen, or petroleum gas as a liquid to reduce volume.
Use concentrated, viscous liquid hand soap for easier dispensing and shared use.
Use adjustable dampers to reduce noise of parts falling into a container.
Vulcanize rubber to change flexibility and durability.
Raise temperature above the Curie point to change ferromagnetic substances to paramagnetic.
Cook food to change taste, aroma, texture, and properties.
Lower temperature of medical specimens to preserve them.

name: Phase transitions
definition: Use phenomena occurring during phase transitions, such as volume change or heat absorption/release.
guidelines: Use phenomena occurring during phase transitions (e.g., volume changes, heat absorption or release).
examples: Use the expansion of water upon freezing to split rocks.
Use heat pumps that exploit heat of vaporization and condensation in a closed thermodynamic cycle.

name: Thermal expansion
definition: Use thermal expansion or contraction, and of materials with different expansion coefficients.
guidelines: Use thermal expansion or contraction of materials.
If thermal expansion is used, employ multiple materials with different coefficients of thermal expansion.
examples: Fit a tight joint by cooling the inner part and heating the outer part, then letting them return to equilibrium.
Use a leaf spring thermostat made of two metals with different expansion coefficients.

name: Strong oxidants
definition: Use oxygen-enriched air, pure oxygen, ionized oxygen, or ozone to intensify reactions or effects.
guidelines: Replace common air with oxygen-enriched air.
Replace enriched air with pure oxygen.
Expose air or oxygen to ionizing radiation.
Use ionized oxygen.
Replace ozonized or ionized oxygen with ozone.
examples: Use Nitrox or other non-air mixtures for scuba diving for extended endurance.
Use an oxy-acetylene torch to cut at higher temperatures.
Treat wounds in a high-pressure oxygen environment to kill anaerobic bacteria and aid healing.
Ionize air to trap pollutants in an air cleaner.
Speed up chemical reactions by ionizing gas before use.

name: Inert atmosphere
definition: Replace a normal environment with an inert one or add neutral parts/additives.
guidelines: Replace a normal environment with an inert one.
Add neutral parts or inert additives to an object.
examples: Prevent degradation of a hot metal filament by using an argon atmosphere.
Increase the volume of powdered detergent by adding inert ingredients to make it easier to measure.

name: Composite materials
definition: Change from uniform materials to composite materials to improve properties.
guidelines: Change from uniform to composite (multiple) materials.
examples: Use composite epoxy resin/carbon fiber golf club shafts that are lighter, stronger, and more flexible than metal.
Use fiberglass surfboards that are lighter, more controllable, and easier to form into various shapes than wooden ones.
